com.versant.util
Class FEProfile

java.lang.Object
  com.versant.util.FEProfile

public class FEProfile
extends java.lang.Object

FEProfile provides setters and getters to read and modify the front end profile of a particular database.

An instance of this class can be obtained by using the DBUtility.getFEProfile(java.lang.String) factory method. Every time an instance of this class is obtained the front end profile is read.

An instance of this class is required to modify the existing front end profile. The front end profile can be modified using DBUtility.writeFEProfile(com.versant.util.FEProfile) method.

For detailed information about each of these profile parameters refer to the VERSANT System Manual.

Method Detail

setAlias

public void setAlias(java.lang.String aliasName,
                     java.lang.String databaseName)
set the alias aliasName for the database databaseName. Calling this method has the same effect as adding this line in the front end profile.

alias gdb1 groupdb1@machine1

where gdb1 is the alias for groupdb1@machine1.

After calling this method, gdb1 can be used in the users application instead of the database name groupdb1@machine1.

Parameters:
aliasName - the alias name
databaseName - the actual name of the database for which the alias is being specified.

addAlias

public void addAlias(java.lang.String aliasName,
                     java.lang.String databaseName)
Add another alias to the Front end profile.

In addition to the existing alias in the front end profile a new alias is added.

Parameters:
aliasName - the alias name.
databaseName - the actual name of the database for which the alias is being specified.

getAliases

public java.util.Properties getAliases()
Get the aliases listed in the front end profile.

Returns:
A Properties object. The keys in the properties object are the aliases and the values are the actual machine names.

setMaxProcess

public void setMaxProcess(int number)
Set the maximum number of process allowed within a session. The default value for the maximum number of processes is 16.

Parameters:
number - the maximum number of processes

getMaxProcess

public int getMaxProcess()
Get the current setting for the maximum number of processes allowed within a session.

Returns:
an integer representing the Maximum number of processes
Throws:
VException - with error number Constants.EVJ_INTERNAL_ERROR in case of a NumberFormatException

setSignalBlock

public void setSignalBlock(boolean status)
Block unwanted signals

Note: This parameter may need to be turned on for an single process application. In single process mode an application makes calls directly to its session database, so if a user hits CTRL-C for example, during a critical moment, the database could become inconsistent.

Parameters:
status - turn signal block on or off.

getSignalBlock

public boolean getSignalBlock()
Get the status of signal block.

Returns:
a boolean which is true if unwanted signals are blocked, false otherwise.

setHeapSizeClassState

public void setHeapSizeClassState(int number,
                                  boolean state)
Allows the state of an individual size class state, expressed as a number from 0 to 31, to be set to a state, either on or off. By default, all size classes are on. This is an advanced tuning parameter that affects how space in the application heap is used.

Example: If size class 2 and 4 is to be turned off this api would be used as follows: 

 
           //get an instance of the front end profile class.
            FEProfile f = DBUtility.getFEProfile("mydb");

            // set the size class states that are of interest to us.
            f.setHeapSizeClass(2, false);
            f.setHeapSizeClass(2, false);

Parameters:
number - The size class number. Size Classes can be between 0 and 31.
state - The state of the size class.

getHeapSizeClassesState

public java.util.Properties getHeapSizeClassesState()
Gets the state of all individual size class states that are set in the FE Profile. Since all size classes from 0 to 31 are on by default, this api returns information for only those size classes that have their state set explicitly in the FE profile.

Returns:
a properties object that contains the sizes as Keys and the states as values. Both the keys and values are stored as Strings in the properties object.

Example: 

 //get an instance of the front end profile
 FEProfile f = DButility.getFEProfile("mydb")
 
 // get the state of size classes
 Properties p = f.getHeapSizeClassesState();

 // check whether size class 2 is on or off
 Boolean sizeClass2State = Boolean.getBoolean(p.get("2"));

setHeapSizeClassSpacing

public void setHeapSizeClassSpacing(int spacing)
Specify the spacing between enabled class size categories.

The default of 0 enables every size class, 1 enables every other size class, 2 enables every third size class, etc. You can use it to manage heap memory tradeoffs in the case of either a small number of allocations or a large number of allocations.

The default value of zero optimizes the case of a large number of allocations. Increasing this reduces memory usage for a small number of allocations, but but increases it for a large number of applications.

Parameters:
spacing - an integer representing the spacing between enabled class size categories.

getHeapSizeClassSpacing

public int getHeapSizeClassSpacing()
Get the current setting for the spacing between enabled class size categories.

Returns:
an integer representing the heap size class spacing.
Throws:
VException - with error number Constants.EVJ_INTERNAL_ERROR in case of a NumberFormatException

setSwapThreshold

public void setSwapThreshold(java.lang.String size)
Specify the application heap size beyond which object swapping begins. If less than this amount of the application heap is used, object swapping will not be attempted by the system. The default swap threshold size is 512M.

Parameters:
size - the application heap size beyond which object swapping begins.

getSwapThreshold

public java.lang.String getSwapThreshold()
Get the current setting for the swap threshold. This setting is the size of the application heap beyond which object swapping begins.

Returns:
a String representing the swap threshold.

getGenericObject

public boolean getGenericObject()
Get the status of generic object

Returns:
a boolean which is true if versioning is on, false otherwise

setGenericObject

public void setGenericObject(boolean status)
Generic object status

Parameters:
status - true if generic_object is to be on, false otherwise The default value is off. If you are using versioning, you may want to want to turn this parameter on. The default version is recorded in a "generic instance" associated with versioned object. There is only one generic object instance for a versioned object. At runtime you can use the generic instance to find the version that has most recently been specified as the default version. See the chapter "Versioning" in the Database Fundamentals Manual for more details.

getLooseSchemaMapping

public boolean getLooseSchemaMapping()
Get the current status of loose schema mapping

Returns:
a boolean value, true if loose schema mapping is used, false otherwise

setLooseSchemaMapping

public void setLooseSchemaMapping(boolean status)
Set the state of the loose schema mapping

Parameters:
status - true if loose schema mapping is to be on, false otherwise

The default state is off.

Normally, when an application accesses a class in a database, VERSANT compares the database definition of the class with the definition expected by the application. If the database and application definitions of the class differ, an exception is raised. If you turn loose schema mapping off, an application compiled with an old class definition can continue to use a database even if class definitions differ.

If loose_schema_mapping is on, the following behavior occurs.

  • If attribute is same in application and database...
    • Create object - OK.
    • Read object - OK.
    • Write object - OK.
  • If attribute exists in database only...
    • Create object - Attribute is set to zero when object is written to database.
    • Read object - Attribute is not seen.
    • Write object - Attribute is not modified when object is written to database.
  • If attribute exists in application only...
    • Create object - Attribute is not written to database.
    • Read object - Attribute is set to zero.
    • Write object - Attribute is not written to database.
  • If attribute type has been changed...
    • Create object - Exception is raised: "types do not match."
    • Read object - Exception is raised: "types do not match."
    • Write object - Exception is raised: "types do not match."
    If loose_schema_mapping is off, the following behavior occurs.

  • If attribute is same in application and database...
    • Create object - OK.
    • Read object - OK.
    • Write object - OK.
  • If attribute exists in database only...
    • Create object - Exception is raised: "signature mismatch" or "wrong layout."
    • Read object - Exception is raised: "signature mismatch" or "wrong layout."
    • Write object - Exception is raised: "signature mismatch" or "wrong layout."
  • If attribute exists in application only...
    • Create object - Exception is raised: "signature mismatch" or "wrong layout."
    • Read object - Exception is raised: "signature mismatch" or "wrong layout."
    • Write object - Exception is raised: "signature mismatch" or "wrong layout."
  • If attribute type has been changed...
    • Create object - Exception is raised: "types do not match."
    • Read object - Exception is raised: "types do not match."
    • Write object - Exception is raised: "types do not match."

    public int getDbConnectTimeout()
    Get the current value of database connect timeout system parameter

    Returns:
    the Operating System TCP/IP driver timeout settings of connect() calls.

    setDbConnectTimeout

    public void setDbConnectTimeout(int number)
    Set database connect timeout This parameter can be used to override the Operating System TCP/IP driver timeout settings of connect() calls. The values accepted for this parameter is an integer in seconds. Non-integer values will result in error

    Parameters:
    number - connect timeout setting in seconds

    setConnectEntry

    public void setConnectEntry(java.lang.String dbName,
                            java.lang.String accessMode)
    Set the "connect" entry in Front End profile Calling this method has the same effect as adding this line in the front end profile.

    connect group_db@machine1 READ_ONLY

    Adding this in front end profile will automatically connect to the group database group_db when you begin a session in READ_ONLY mode. Specify remote databases with db@node syntax. Connections to databases made using the connect parameter can be disconnected by calling a "disconnect database" routine from within a session. Otherwise, the connections will be terminated when you end the session.
    For example :

    If you wish to connect to a group database named groupdb1 on machine1 every time you begin a session, use following -

    FEProfile feProf = DBUtility.getFEProfile("group_db@machineX"); feProf.setConnectEntry("group1@machine1", "READ_WRITE");

    Parameters:
    dbName - the group database name to which you wish to connect
    accessMode -

    Access modes are specified as:

  • READ_ONLY - Read only.
  • READ_WRITE - Read and write.
  • WRITE_ONLY - Write only.

    • getConnectEntry

    public java.util.Properties getConnectEntry()
    Get the connect entries listed in the front end profile.

    Returns:
    A Properties object. The keys in the properties object are the database name and the value are their access mode.

    addConnectEntry

    public void addConnectEntry(java.lang.String dbName,
                            java.lang.String accessMode)
    Add another connect entry to the Front end profile.

    In addition to the existing connect entry in the front end profile a new connect entry is added.

    Parameters:
    dbName - the group database name to which you wish to connect
    accessMode -

    Access modes are specified as:

  • READ_ONLY - Read only.
  • READ_WRITE - Read and write.
  • WRITE_ONLY - Write only.
